docs.abstract: James Barron article recalls notable events of 2001, year that began quietly but was ultimately dominated by terrorist attacks of Sept 11; photos (Special section The Year in Pictures) (M)

headline.main: The Year in Pictures: IN THE TOWERS' SHADOW

docs.snippet: So overpowering are the images of jetliners heading into the World Trade Center, of people watching in disbelief and fleeing in horror, that the other news of 2001, significant and not so significant, already fades from memory. And some of it was ...
docs.lead_paragraph: So overpowering are the images of jetliners heading into the World Trade Center, of people watching in disbelief and fleeing in horror, that the other news of 2001, significant and not so significant, already fades from memory. And some of it was significant. There was the swearing in of a president after the Supreme Court decided the presidential election. There was the death of the legendary driver Dale Earnhardt in a stock car crash. There was Cal Ripken's retirement after 3,001 games, including a record 2,632 in a row (and 3,184 hits, 1,695 runs batted in and 431 homers). There was Robert Tools's quiet thumbs-up after becoming the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart. But on a gleaming late-summer morning, there were those planes bearing down on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Suddenly, Americans had no sense of what the future might bring. As the shock and the tears subsided, faces that had been purposeful were newly diffident. And in the changed world of politics, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, prevented by New York City's term-limits law from seeking a third term, prepared to leave City Hall celebrating his much-heralded leadership.

docs.abstract: On Pro Football column describes Philadelphia Eagles thrilling come-from-behind victory over New York Giants, ending Giants playoff hopes; photo (M)

headline.main: Thrash's Long Route Takes Many Twists

docs.snippet: The moon was full over Veterans Stadium and the old joint was stacked full of fans, and pretty soon Thunder and Lightning appeared in the form of Giants running backs Ron Dayne and Tiki Barber.     When the Giants jumped ahead of Philadelphia, 21-...
docs.lead_paragraph: The moon was full over Veterans Stadium and the old joint was stacked full of fans, and pretty soon Thunder and Lightning appeared in the form of Giants running backs Ron Dayne and Tiki Barber. When the Giants jumped ahead of Philadelphia, 21-14, with 2 minutes 43 seconds remaining on Dayne's 16-yard run, Dayne had rushed for 59 yards, Barber for 71, the Giants' suddenly spirited offense had scored 11 points in the fourth quarter, capped by Barber's 2-yard conversion run, and it looked as if the Giants had put the Eagles back in their place:

docs.abstract: Impressions in Afghanistan and at World Trade Center remains recorded by New York Times reporter C J Chivers after spending time and reporting from both sites; in both places, he finds that it is often chance that determines where someone will be and if person will live or die; photos (M)

headline.main: Two Worlds Paired by War: Life or Death, as Luck Will Have It

docs.snippet: The sniper sat behind sandbags on the roof of the American Embassy as the sun dropped behind the Paghman Mountains and the sky began to fade. A camp stove at his knee exhaled the stink of diesel and a steady hiss.    His name was Sgt. Shane B. Sch...
docs.lead_paragraph: The sniper sat behind sandbags on the roof of the American Embassy as the sun dropped behind the Paghman Mountains and the sky began to fade. A camp stove at his knee exhaled the stink of diesel and a steady hiss. His name was Sgt. Shane B. Schmidt. He was a marine. This was his bunker. To his left was a bolt-action rifle with a telescopic sight. To his right were five candy canes hanging on a cord. Sergeant Schmidt had been vacationing in Wisconsin when the hijacked jetliners knocked the World Trade Center down. Watching it happen live on television, he said, ''was like being a boxer who couldn't hit back.''

docs.snippet: Photo of ball that will be dropped at midnight in Times Square New Year's celebration...

docs.abstract: Afghanistan left behind by fleeing Taliban is sad and broken land; in five years that Taliban ruled, one million refugees joined million others who already left and refused to come home, and six million Afghans, quarter of country, are unable to find enough food; real legacy of Taliban rule lies deeper; journey around country reveals deep psychological wounds in people still struggling with torment of government regarded by many as oppressive and strange; nearly one in eight families in Kabul is believed to be headed by widows, and most have children; under Taliban, they were not permitted to work; Taliban flourished outside gaze of world's remaining superpower, United States, finally giving succor to terrorists that would invite its own doom; photos (L)

headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: RISE AND FALL
headline.main: The Legacy of the Taliban Is a Sad and Broken Land

docs.snippet: When the last of the Taliban fled into the desert three weeks ago, the neighbors of Mullah Muhammad Omar wasted no time in celebrating his downfall.     They rushed to the madrasa, the religious school he built more than a decade ago, tore the woo...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the last of the Taliban fled into the desert three weeks ago, the neighbors of Mullah Muhammad Omar wasted no time in celebrating his downfall. They rushed to the madrasa, the religious school he built more than a decade ago, tore the wood frames off the doors and window panes and burned them for heat. They carried the straw mats to their homes, boxed up the books that Mullah Omar regarded as too important to be handled by the local boys.

docs.abstract: Times Square Business Improvement District is weighing new security measures in response to terrorist attack on World Trade Center, some of which would likely lead to clashes with civil liberties groups and urban planners (M)

headline.main: Panel Weighs New Methods For Security In Times Sq.

docs.snippet: The Times Square Business Improvement District is weighing new security measures in response to the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, some of which would be likely to lead to clashes with civil liberties groups and urban planners.     Ma...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Times Square Business Improvement District is weighing new security measures in response to the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, some of which would be likely to lead to clashes with civil liberties groups and urban planners. Many of the ideas under discussion -- like encouraging building owners to coat their windows to protect against shattering or asking for bomb-resistant trash cans -- would simply make use of up-to-date technology and would not affect the way the public experiences Times Square.

docs.snippet: The Military Campaign    ARMY TO RELIEVE MARINES -- The Pentagon ordered soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division to relieve the Marine Corps in southern Afghanistan, paving the way for a long-term American military presence in the country. The A...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Military Campaign ARMY TO RELIEVE MARINES -- The Pentagon ordered soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division to relieve the Marine Corps in southern Afghanistan, paving the way for a long-term American military presence in the country. The Army's mission will be essentially the same as that of the marines: guarding Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners awaiting interrogation, securing an airfield for planes carrying military and relief supplies, and searching for remnants of the Taliban army near Kandahar. A1

docs.abstract: Michael Kimmelman Critic's Notebook article on touring London art exhibitions (M)

headline.main: London Revels In Art, Cheeky Or Grandiose

docs.snippet: Tate Britain has expanded. The British galleries at the Victoria and Albert have just opened. And at the Courtauld ''Art on the Line,'' an excellent show, celebrates the coming of age of British art in the annual exhibitions that took place in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Tate Britain has expanded. The British galleries at the Victoria and Albert have just opened. And at the Courtauld ''Art on the Line,'' an excellent show, celebrates the coming of age of British art in the annual exhibitions that took place in the Great Room at Somerset House starting in the late 18th century. In other words London is everywhere tooting its own horn again. So I set out the other day to look at Japanese art from the collection of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

docs.abstract: New York Jets blame wind gusts for some of their troubles against Buffalo Bills; running back Curtis Martin gains 100 yards in game, seventh time this season; game stats (M)

headline.main: Wind Proves To Be a Foe

docs.snippet: The wind blew from 15 to 25 miles an hour today at Giants Stadium, and it affected the Jets' decision making.    Coach Herman Edwards said the Jets chose to play with the wind at their backs to start the game. The Jets hoped to make the Bills punt...
docs.lead_paragraph: The wind blew from 15 to 25 miles an hour today at Giants Stadium, and it affected the Jets' decision making. Coach Herman Edwards said the Jets chose to play with the wind at their backs to start the game. The Jets hoped to make the Bills punt into the wind early. That would give the Jets good field position and a chance at a fast start. That backfired immediately when the Bills' first punt went 47 yards.

docs.abstract: Pakistan reports arrest of Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, founder of one of two Islamic militant groups accused by India of mounting attack on Indian Parliament 18 days ago; action appears to be last-ditch effort to forestall war with India; Pakistani officials have hinted that Gen Pervez Musharraf is ready to take 'new and bolder' steps to crack down on Saeed's Army of the Pure and second group, Army of Muhammad; Army of Muhammad leader, Maulana Masood Azhar, was arrested week ago; Pakistan also froze bank accounts of both groups; State Dept has added both groups to its list of banned terrorist organizations; arrests fail to mollify India or US, which continue to push for additional steps that would bring Pakistan closer to meeting India's demands that groups be suppressed and their leaders handed over to India for trial; photos; map (M)

headline.main: Pakistan Is Reported to Have Arrested Militant Leader

docs.snippet: In what appeared to be a last-ditch effort to forestall war with India, Pakistan was reported this morning to have arrested Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of one of two Islamic militant groups accused by India of mounting an attack on the India...
docs.lead_paragraph: In what appeared to be a last-ditch effort to forestall war with India, Pakistan was reported this morning to have arrested Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of one of two Islamic militant groups accused by India of mounting an attack on the Indian Parliament 18 days ago. Reports by the Reuters and Agence France-Presse news services that appeared after midnight on Sunday in Islamabad quoted an unnamed senior security official as saying that Mr. Saeed, founder and leader until last week of the Army of the Pure, had been arrested ''for making inflammatory speeches to incite people to violate law and order.'' The arrest had appeared to be imminent for several days as Pakistan sought ways of defusing the crisis with India.
